feed.title: Category: picks | User group for Viennese rubyists

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
08/5 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we'll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies... you're in for an eclectic mix! So, here's for the fourth edition:

Andy:
  • Testing Tuesday #4: Continuous Integration and Deployment with Cucumber - codeship.io has a great series testing and deployment you should follow.
  • Writing a good README - Why a good README is important and a few tricks that help you with it.
  • Birth and death of a running programm - A deeper look on the lifecycle of a C program.
Tony:
  • The Daily WTF - relax and laugh - or choke on the worst code you'll ever see.
  • Relish - Living documentation (if you use cucumber). Including RSpec, cucumber, mongoid, diaspora et al.
  • Draper - Decorators for Rails Applications
Floor:
  • git eep - Fellow vienna.rb'er Tony wrote some great stuff about how to deal with git on his 'blag'.
  • Vincent & Emily - Modern day love story.
  • Compuritas - This Austrian startup collects old hardware, repairs, reconditions it, and sells it to people who, otherwise, would not be able to afford it.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
01/5 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we'll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies... you're in for an eclectic mix! So, here's for the third edition:

Andy:
  • The Most Difficult Bug - How to solve the most difficult bug of them all.
  • Building a Ruby Library - 'Building a Ruby Library, the part no one talks about', great talk by Mitchell Hashimoto, at Aloha Ruby Conf.
  • color theme - An Emacs color theme based on Heroku.
Tony:
  • Clean Coders - Code Casts for Software Professionals. Check out the first vid in the clean code series for a sneak peek. Not for free, but full of value.
  • Method Finder - a smalltalk like method finder for ruby. A real smart piece of software, and useful for beginners and professionals.
  • Her - an ORM (Object Relational Mapper) that maps REST resources to Ruby objects. Much more configurable and easier to use than ActiveResource.
Floor:
  • bieber.ly - The best url shortener EVER. Thank you, Elliott Kember.
  • gizoogle - Fo' all y'all biotches who wanna find shiznit!
  • Railsberry revisited - What happened at Railsberry centainly did not stay at Railsberry. I tried to write a few recaps, you'll find them on my Tumblr.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
24/4 Picks!!

In a little series on this website we'll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies... you're in for an eclectic mix! So, here's for the second edition:

Andy:
  • git-code-review - An extension to git to help you with doing regular code reviews of other team members' commits.
  • Essentials of Garbage Collection - This is a very nice approach on understanding how GC works and what it does.
  • If you are busy you do it wrong - A bit older, but shows you why 'elite performers' perform the way they do. It's not only the genius that matters.
Tony:
  • git-wtf - a script to display the state of your repository in a readable and easy-to-scan format.
  • Benchmarking in Ruby - a short overview and nice examples.
  • Sequel - The Database Toolkit for Ruby (especially if you use PostgreSQL)
Floor:
  • tmux Quick Start - Just what I needed: a brief introduction to what tmux can do and how it works.
  • Glitché - Ridiculous, but oh so awesome: Glitché (iPhone app) Distort your photos using computer errors and bugs
  • Karaoke - There's a KaraokeParty at the Metalab this Friday. You don't want to miss that for the world. Believe me.

entry.title: Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week
entry.content:
Picks / what the vienna.rb team thinks is worth sharing this week

In a little series on this website we'll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, funsies... you're in for an eclectic mix! So, here's to the first edition:

Andy:
  • CodeTriage - Help your favorite open source projects. They have bugs, they need help!
  • Why does it call the "wrong" equal method? - on Stack Overflow - The title is pretty much selfexplainatory.
  • Return to the Essence of Text Editing - Emacs is a pretty neat everything, but also a decent text editor.
Tony:
  • Objects On Rails - a "developer's notebook" documenting some guidelines, techniques, and ideas for applying classic object-oriented thought to Ruby on Rails applications.
  • Clean Coders - educational videos for software professionals, by software professionals.
  • vim-rails - vim is the best rails editor of all times.
Floor:
  • Bootstrap HTML Button generator - Bootstrapping buttons. Because why would you want to reinvent the wheel?
  • List of Hello World Programs in 300 Programming Languages - A complete list of “Hello World!” programs written in more than 300 existing programming languages including Assembly language, Low-level, High-level, Object Oriented, Document formats, Page description languages and Scripting languages. How awesome is that?
  • starlogs.net - Putting Geek in GitHub. Once more.
